#Text=Marimba Ani

#Text=Marimba Ani ( born Dona Richards ) is an anthropologist and African Studies scholar best known for her work Yurugu , a comprehensive critique of European thought and culture , and her coining of the term " Maafa " for the African holocaust .
#Text=Life and work
#Text=Marimba Ani completed her BA degree at the University of Chicago , and holds MA and Ph.D. degrees in anthropology from the Graduate Faculty of the New School University . [ 1 ]
#Text=In 1964 , during Freedom Summer , she served as an SNCC field secretary , and married civil-rights activist Bob Moses ; they divorced in 1966 . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]

#Text=She has taught as a Professor of African Studies in the Department of Black and Puerto Rican Studies at Hunter College in New York City , [ 1 ] [ 3 ] and is credited with introducing the term Maafa to describe the African holocaust . [ 4 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=Yurugu

#Text=Ani 's 1994 work , Yurugu : An Afrikan-Centered Critique of European Cultural Thought and Behavior , examined the influence of European culture on the formation of modern institutional frameworks , through colonialism and imperialism , from an African perspective . [ 6 ] [ 7 ] [ 8 ] Described by the author as an " intentionally aggressive polemic " , the book derives its title from a Dogon legend of an incomplete and destructive being rejected by its creator . [ 9 ] [ 10 ]

column1: #Text=Examining the causes of global white supremacy , Ani argued that European thought implicitly believes in its own superiority , stating : " European culture is unique in the assertion of political interest " . [ 6 ]
#Text=In Yurugu , Ani proposed a tripartite conceptualization of culture , based on the concepts of
#Text=Asili , the central seed or " germinating matrix " of a culture ,
#Text=Utamawazo , " culturally structured thought " or worldview , " the way in which the thought of members of a culture must be patterned if the asili is to be fulfilled " , and
#Text=Utamaroho , a culture 's " vital force " or " energy source " , which " gives it its emotional tone and motivates the collective behavior of its members " . [ 8 ] [ 9 ] [ 11 ]

column1: #Text=The terms Ani uses in this framework are based on Swahili .

#Text=Asili is a common Swahili word meaning " origin " or " essence " ; utamawazo and utamaroho are neologisms created by Ani , based on the Swahili words utamaduni ( " civilisation " ) , wazo ( " thought " ) and roho ( " spirit life " ) . [ 9 ] [ 12 ] [ 13 ]

column1: #Text=The utamawazo and utamaroho are not viewed as separate from the asili , but as its manifestations , which are " born out of the asili and , in turn , affirm it . " [ 11 ]

#Text=Ani characterised the asili of European culture as dominated by the concepts of separation and control , with separation establishing dichotomies like " man " and " nature " , " the European " and " the other " , " thought " and " emotion " – separations that in effect end up negating the existence of " the other " , who or which becomes subservient to the needs of ( European ) man . [ 8 ]

column1: #Text=Control is disguised in universalism as in reality " the use of abstract ' universal ' formulations in the European experience has been to control people , to impress them , and to intimidate them . " [ 14 ]

#Text=According to Ani 's model , the utamawazo of European culture " is structured by ideology and bio-cultural experience " , and its utamaroho or vital force is domination , reflected in all European-based structures and the imposition of Western values and civilisation on peoples around the world , destroying cultures and languages in the name of progress . [ 8 ] [ 15 ]
#Text=The book also addresses the use of the term Maafa , based on a Swahili word meaning " great disaster " , to describe slavery .
#Text=African-centered thinkers have subsequently popularized and expanded on Ani 's conceptualization . [ 16 ]

#Text=Citing both the centuries-long history of slavery and more recent examples like the Tuskegee study , Ani argued that Europeans and white Americans have an " enormous capacity for the perpetration of physical violence against other cultures " that had resulted in " antihuman , genocidal " treatment of blacks . [ 16 ] [ 17 ]

column1: #Text=Critical reception

#Text=Philip Higgs , in African Voices in Education , describes Yurugu as an " excellent delineation of the ethics of harmonious coexistence between human beings " , but cites the book 's " overlooking of structures of social inequality and conflict that one finds in all societies , including indigenous ones , " as a weakness . [ 15 ] :175

column1: #Text=Molefi Kete Asante describes Yurugu as an " elegant work " . [ 18 ]

#Text=Stephen Howe accuses Ani of having little interest in actual Africa ( beyond romance ) and challenges her critique of " Eurocentric " logic since she invests heavily in its usage in the book . [ 9 ]
